section.title: Description
section.para: The OmegaT interface generally does not rely on buttons to give access to its functions. Instead, they are called from the menus or, for the majority of functions, from their assigned default shortcut.

Learning the most frequent shortcuts will not take long once you start working with OmegaT. The shortcuts are indicated next to each menu item, allowing them to learn new shortcuts gradually as you use the software.
You can customize the majority of the shortcuts in OmegaT. See for details.

OmegaT runs on any platform that runs a Java Runtime Environment (Windows, macOS, and Linux being the most mainstream). The modifier keys that form the shortcuts vary slightly depending between platforms. To make reading easier we have adopted the following convention for modifier keys:
Modifier key identifiers
Linux/Windows Key identifier macOS
Shift S shift or ⇧
Ctrl or Control C command or ⌘
Alt A alt / option or ⌥
Ctrl control or ⌃
The Key identifiers above enable us to avoid listing multiple notations for every shortcut.

example.title: How we avoid listing multiple notations:
example.para: On Windows and Linux: CtrlShiftN
On macOS: ShiftCommandN
In this manual: CSN

section.title: A shortcut based workflow
section.para: Remembering the main editing and navigation shortcuts (or modifying them to suit your needs) can help you streamline your work.
This is best illustrated with an example:

example.title: Using shortcuts to streamline the translation process
example.para: Picture a technical translator tasked with translating an updated version of a manual from a previous job.
Since the first few pages have not changed, the translator is greeted with a screenful of already translated segments from the previous job's memory upon opening the project.

Rather than tediously scroll down until she finds the first segment to translate, the translator quickly presses CU to jump straight into the action and start translating. (And doing so again each time she reaches a large unchanged section.)

A few segments later, the translator comes across a term she should add to the glossary. Instead of reaching for the mouse, she unlocks the cursor with F2, uses the cursor keys and standard system shortcuts to navigate to the term and select it, and then presses CSG to call up the glossary entry dialog to enter the source term, and then switches back to the editor and repeats the process to enter the target term.
The translator has enabled the to automatically display not only history predictions, but also glossary terms, and pre-defined short strings, which can be entered with simple arrow navigation.
The translator then reaches a revised section of the text where the pane shows a number of similar segments from the previous job.

After quickly tapping CI to insert the match, she makes the necessary changes to match the revised text. This continues, with the occasional sequence of C2 (or other number) followed by CI when one of the matches from 2 to 5 is more suitable.

By the time she gets near the end of the section, she has also used CR once or twice to replace already automatically entered fuzzy matches from the previous translation with better matches from earlier in the current section.

Later on, the translator comes up with a better way to phrase a somewhat thorny expression that had come up earlier, so she selects it in the source text, presses CF to find it, and then uses CJ to immediately jump to that segment from the search dialog.
Since OmegaT has registered her navigation history, she only needs to use CSJ to immediately continue from where she left off.

Time for a break. As she savours her coffee, the translator reflects on how much more smoothly she was able to use the various OmegaT functions compared to when she had just gotten started and spent a lot of time clicking through menus.
The smoother workfow, in turn, allowed her to better focus on the translation itself.

At the same time, the translator realized that during her session, she used the menu and cursor keys to select the function several times, and decides to add a new shortcut to streamline that part of the process as well.

section.para: Taking the time to learn the shortcuts for the functions you use often will be well worth your while.

section.title: Customization
section.para: OmegaT assigns shortcuts to most of the functions available in the , , and menus and to a number of functions in the Editor window. You can also add or modify the shortcuts for most of the functions.
To do so, you have to put the appropriate shortcut definition file in your OmegaT configuration folder. See for details.
There are two shortcut definition files.

listitem.para: The shortcut definition file for the menus and a few other items.
The shortcut definition file for the editor.

section.para: OmegaT must be restarted after a shortcut definition file has been modified for the new shortcuts to take effect.

note.para: You can copy the default OmegaT shortcut files from the OmegaT development site on Sourceforge to your configuration folder and modify them to suit your needs:
The macOS files must be renamed and for OmegaT to recognize them.

section.para: The next section describes the syntax used in the shortcut definition files, and provides an example modification.

section.title: Syntax
section.para: The basic syntax of the shortcut definitions files is simply:
Use the tables in the section below to find the values for function code.

The shortcut represents the key combination pressed by the user. It takes the following form:
0 or more modifier
followed by 0 or 1 event
followed by 1 key
where:

listitem.para: modifier can be: shift, ctrl, meta, alt, or altGraph

note.para: meta refers to the key with the Windows logo on most keyboards for Windows or Linux systems, and to the command on macOS.
altGraph refers to the Alt key to the right of the spacebar on keyboards with two Alt keys.

listitem.para: event can be: typed, pressed, released
and key can be any key available on your keyboard. You can refer to the table presenting the different editor shortcuts to find the values for keys such as Home, Page Up, or the arrow keys.

section.para: Empty lines and comments can be added to organize the list and make it easier to read. A comment line starts with a #, and everything after that is ignored by the applicaton.
The easiest way to modify the shortcuts is to download copies of the default files to your configuration folder, as noted above, and make the changes you want there.

example.title: Modifying a shortcut
example.para:
The default shortcut for closing a project is defined as:
projectCloseMenuItem=ctrl shift W
on Windows and Linux, and as
projectCloseMenuItem=meta shift W
on macOS.

However, you may want to remove the S key from the shortcut to make it only CtrlW (or CommandW on macOS) to match the shortcut you use in other applications. To do so, modify the MainMenuShortcuts.properties as follows:
projectCloseMenuItem=ctrl W
in Windows or Linux, or

projectCloseMenuItem=meta W
on macOS.

example.title: Adding a shortcut
example.para: If your language pair calls for the frequent use alternative translations, you may want to assign a shortcut to that function since it does not have one by default.

The steps below demonstrate how to assign the AltX shortcut to the function.
Open the MainMenuShortcuts.properties you have copied to your configuration folder in a text editor.
As shown in the Edit menu table below, the function code for the Create Alternative Translation function is editMultipleAlternate.
Searching for that code in the file will bring you to the following line:
# editMultipleAlternate=
The line is currently a comment. Delete the # at the beginning of the line so OmegaT will recognize the shortcut, and add alt X after the = sign at the end of the line:
editMultipleAlternate=alt X
Save and close the file. The next time you start OmegaT, you your new shortcut should be active and displayed next to the name of the function in the menu.

section.para: Save the file after you have finished making your changes. If OmegaT is open, you will have to restart it for your changes to take effect.

Your modified or added shortcuts should now be displayed next to the menu items you have changed. They will now be availabe in OmegaT as long as there are no conflicts with other functions or with system-wide shortcuts.
